citation.article-title: Methanocalculus pumilus sp. nov., a heavy-metal-tolerant methanogen isolated from a waste-disposal site.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Methanocalculus pumilus sp. nov.
Methanocalculus pumilus (pu'mi.lus. L. adj. pumilus little)
Cells are irregular cocci 0.8-1.0 μm in diameter and occur singly.
Susceptibility to lysis by SDS (0.1 g l-1) and by hypotonic conditions is observed.
Growth occurs between 25 and 45 °C, with an optimum at 35 °C.
The pH range for growth is 5.5-9.0, with an optimum around neutral pH.
Growth occurs at NaCl concentrations between 0 and 7%, with an optimum at 1.0%.
The doubling time is approximately 12 h under optimum conditions.
The substrates used for growth and methanogenesis are H2/CO2 and formate, but not acetate, pyruvate, glucose, trimethylamine, methanol, ethanol, 1-propanol, 2-propanol, 1-butanol or 2-butanol.
The G+­C content of the DNA is 51.9 mol%(as determined by HPLC).
The type strain is Methanocalculus pumilus MHT-1T, which was isolated from leachate at a waste-disposal site in Osaka, Japan.
Strain MHT-1T has been deposited in the DSMZ-Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen und Zellkulturen (DSM 12632T) and the Japan Collection of Microorganisms (JCM 10627T).
